abstract.text: As COVID-19 infection spreads globally, the demand for chest imaging will inevitably rise with an 2 accompanying increase in risk of disease transmission to frontline radiology staff. Radiology 3 departments should implement strict infection control measures and robust operational plans to 4

Harnessing on experience and lessons from SARS outbreak in Singapore in 2003, the authors would like to share operational guidelines and strategies implemented in our practice to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission and mitigate the impact of possible intra-department staff transmission.
The novel coronavirus

Concern by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 30 January 2020 [1] . As of 22 Mar 2020, there 26 were 306,893 reported cases worldwide with 13,026 deaths. COVID-19 spreads mainly via 27 respiratory droplets and contact transmission [2, 3] , resulting in varying degrees of lower respiratory 28 tract symptoms. Radiology hence plays a key role in the management of COVID-19 infection with the 29 use of chest X-ray (CXR) and Computed Tomography (CT) [4] in screening, diagnosis and 30 prognostication of disease [2, 3, [5] [6] [7] . 31

body_text.text: As a new condition, a number of papers have been recently published [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] to familiarize radiologists 32 with its imaging appearance but few have dealt with the more practical operational challenges faced 33 [8] [9] [10] [11] . With an anticipated worldwide increase in COVID-19 cases, the demand for chest imaging will 34
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: inevitably rise with an accompanying increase in exposure and risk of disease transmission to 35 frontline radiology staff. Harnessing on our experience and lessons from SARS (Severe Acute 36
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: Respiratory Syndrome) outbreak in Singapore in 2003, the authors would like to share the 37 operational guidelines and strategies implemented in our practice to reduce the risk of and to mitigate the impact of possible intra-39 department staff transmission. While these strategies may not be directly applicable to all 40 institutions due to inherent social, cultural, geographical and economic differences, the authors 41 believe the underlying principles and rationale of implemented strategies remain relevant and can 42 be adopted or modified by other institutions for their practice in dealing with the current COVID-19 43 outbreak. 44
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: Broadly, the strategies can be divided into the following categories: 45 The demand for portable CXRs will rise tremendously. Our department experienced a 3-fold increase 52 in portable CXR numbers from the emergency department (EMD) alone with at least 100 portable 53
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: CXRs performed daily since the start of the outbreak. As such, our department has allocated half of 54 the available portable x-ray machines to EMD to cope with the outbreak. 55
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: Similar to the SARS outbreak in 2003, hospital EMDs have set up outdoor extensions or tents (i.e. 56 colloquially termed "fever facility") with portable digital radiography services to effectively triage 57 patients. The immediate priority is to identify case suspects (i.e. patients with symptoms concerning 58 for COVID19 +/-relevant contact or travel history which are updated daily by local health authorities 59 according to global situation) and manage them separately from low-risk patients to minimize 60 disease transmission. A sample layout of the "fever facility" is shown in Figure 1 . 61
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: For patients who require imaging depending on protocol or physician's discretion, portable CXRs are 62 performed in these "fever facilities" to minimize patient transportation and risk of disease spread. In 63 addition, dedicated portable x-ray machines with a separate set of cassettes are allocated for case 64 suspects in isolation areas to reduce cross-contamination with other low-risk patients. Some other 65 hospitals in Singapore had to pre-emptively rent additional portable x-ray units to handle the 66 increased demand [8] . Hence, radiology departments should consider and assess the adequacy of 67 existing portable facilities during this period. 68
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: For patients who require CT scans, portable CT scanners can be a potential solution but many 69 institutions could face economic and logistical challenges (i.e. space constraint) during 70 implementation. As an alternative, our department designated a dedicated CT scanner with shortest 71 distance to isolation wards for case suspects to prevent contamination to other CT scanners.
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: We also experienced an increase in manpower demand due to a number of factors including: (1) 74
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: Increased workload in certain modalities (e.g. portable CXRs) with necessary quick turn-around-75 times, (2) Increased time required to perform procedures for case suspects due to additional 76 precautions required and (3) Limitation of staff cross-coverage due to team segregation strategies 77 (see strategy #3 below). 78
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: Radiology departments should ensure manpower adequacy during this period as the situation may 79 potentially worsen and manpower resources could also deplete exponentially if staff infection and 80 quarantine occurs. As such, in Singapore, we have frozen non-essential overseas leave and 81 conference leave for public healthcare workers [8] with financial reimbursements for leave 82 cancellations. Local leave is still granted as staff can be recalled to work quickly if unforeseen 83 circumstances arise. 84
body_text.section: outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International 25

body_text.text: There is a huge demand for PPE world-wide. Fortunately, we have learnt to stockpile PPE on a 86 national and hospital level from the SARS experience to ensure adequate supply for our frontline 87 staff. This is in line with the pandemic response plan published in 2004 by Singapore Ministry of 88
Health [12] , which advised institutes to maintain a 3-6 month stockpile of PPE. Mask-fitting exercises 89
have also been carried out on a regular (~3 yearly) basis to keep staff updated on their mask sizes. 90

Within the department, equipment is distributed to staff daily at designated sites to ensure 91 accountability and sustainability of PPE stock. Frontline staff (e.g. radiographers) are also updated on 92 the latest policies, via emails or e-learning hospital intranet modules, on handling droplet and 93 contact precaution patients with instructions on the proper donning, use and removal of PPE. 94

Strict Adherence to PPE guidelines All staff are required to wear surgical masks when on clinical duty. The use of PPE with fluid-resistant 97 characteristics, disposable gloves with coverage over gown cuff, eye protection (including face 98 shields or goggles) and fit-tested N95 or higher face mask is mandatory when handling suspected or 99 confirmed COVID-19 patients [13] . Our department also advocates the double glove practice with 100 the outermost layer of gloves changed between every patient. The inner layer of gloves are not 101 removed when cleaning surfaces that had patient contact to minimize the risk of contact 102 transmission [14] . 103

The following guidelines were implemented in our institute to reduce the risk of cross contamination 105 for non-portable modalities, such as CT or MRI. Non-urgent scan requests were postponed until the 106 confirmation of COVID-19 diagnosis. If a scan is deemed urgent, it is scheduled as the last case of the 107 morning or afternoon session on a dedicated scanner, to minimize disease transmission between 108 patients and to allow abundant time for cleaning and airing of room before the next scan. A specific 109 route of transportation is used between the isolation wards and the imaging department. Hospital 110 security is engaged to clear human traffic along this route to minimize exposure or transmission 111 between the patient and the public/staff. 112
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: Upon arrival at the scan room, the patient is attended to by two separate radiographers. The 113 radiographer who has direct contact with the patient is designated the "dirty" radiographer; ("dirty" 114 being the colloquial term for "high risk for potential contamination and/or exposure to COVID-19). 115
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: The "dirty" radiographer performs hand hygiene and dons full PPE with double gloves, and is 116 responsible for (1) positioning patient for scan, (2) moving patient off scanner and (3) cleaning of 117 equipment after scan completion. The "clean" radiographer remains stationed in the scan room to 118 operate the scanner. The separation of clean, dirty (or potentially contaminated) and changing areas 119 are illustrated in Figure 2 . 120 There had been constant efforts to improve hygiene awareness ever since the SARS outbreak in 122
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: 2003. For example, departments are regularly assessed on hand hygiene standards by an infection 123 control team and results are used for department appraisals. The COVID-19 outbreak only served to 124 heighten hygiene standards all-round. In addition, temperature monitoring of staff has been 125 instituted. Thermometers were issued to staff so they can record their temperature readings daily. 126
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: Staff who feel unwell are also advised against coming to work. 127
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: Rigorous measures have also been taken to clean and disinfect radiology equipment. Single use 128 disposable plastic sheets are used for lining of CT scan couches for case suspects. After disposal, the 129 surfaces are wiped down with Isopropyl Alcohol 70%. Terminal cleaning of the scan room by 130 housekeeping staff is also carried out by using diluted bleach solution (6mg Chlorine releasing 131 disinfectant tablet to 1000ml of water) to wipe down the machine, walls and floor. As we do not 132 have negative air pressure room for our CT scanner, the scan room is aired for at least 30 minutes to 133 allow the cleaned surfaces to dry adequately before proceeding to scan another patient. 134
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: For portable x-ray machines, deep cleaning is performed twice a day using diluted bleach solution to 135 wipe down the machine exteriorly. For parts of the machine that are delicate (e.g. collimators, 136 control console, exposure buttons etc.), Isopropyl Alcohol 70% rather than bleach is used for 137 cleaning after every patient. For detailed guidelines on equipment disinfection, staff should seek 138 advice from their specific equipment vendors. 139
body_text.section: CT and MRI Scan Protocols for High-Risk Patients 104

body_text.text: Gaining experience from SARS outbreak in 2003, local radiology departments have adopted team 141 segregation strategies to (1) reduce risk of human-to-human transmission with team quarantine in 142 the event of staff infection while (2) maintaining the capabilities to meet the hospital needs [8] . The 143 department is hence split into independent teams, each comprising of selected individuals with 144 different skillsets (i.e. radiologists, radiographers, nurses etc.) to serve the daily hospital needs. In 145 our institution, we adopted a combination of temporal and physical segregation strategies.

The rationale behind temporal segregation is due to the inherent incubation period of Asymptomatic infected staff may be a potential source of human-to-human transmission at work 149 [15] . With reported potential incubation periods of up to 2 weeks [16] for COVID-19, trial runs of 150 split teams in temporal "2+2" format have been suggested by the Chinese Society of Imaging 151

Technology in an expert consensus article [9] . In this "2+2" format, staff who are at high-risk (e.g. 152 frontline radiographers, sonographers, interventional radiologists etc.) are split into 2 groups. The 153 first group works 2 weeks consecutively while the second group rests and 'self-quarantines' at home. 154 A swap-over happens at the end of the 2-week period. 155 However, this "2+2" format faces many potential challenges in our experience. Firstly, not all 156 radiology departments can afford for many of its staff to be self-quarantined during this period of 157 high manpower demand. Secondly, working in a high-risk environment and being constantly gowned 158 in PPE for 14 days consecutively can be physically and mentally exhausting for staff. As the outbreak 159 prolongs, this arrangement may not be sustainable or ideal for team morale and efficiency. 160

As such, we decided to adopt a more sustainable "1+1" variation, given that most symptoms show 161 up within the first 6.4 days (95% CI: 5.6 -7.7 days) of infection [16] . In addition, staff are rotated to 162 'low-risk' areas instead of home quarantine after their shift in the 'high-risk' zones to minimize 163 impact on manpower. An example of this would be for an interventional radiologist to go on a 1-164

week shift of reporting diagnostic imaging studies with no patient contact, following a 1-week shift 165 of performing interventional procedures with patient contact. Implementation of temporal 166 strategies is cumbersome from the rota planning perspective, but would be critically important if 167 staff transmission truly occurs. 168

On a national level, physical segregation involves prohibiting staff from working in different hospitals 170 except in critical subspecialties with limited expertise (e.g. neurointervention). Staff are now 171 restricted to working in a single defined hospital to reduce the risk of inter-hospital virus 172 transmission. The same principle applies to radiology resident rotations between hospitals. 173

Adjustments to the residents' training have been made to allow them to continue at their respective 174 hospitals. These strategies are not expected to cause major issues due to the vast improvements in 175 technology since SARS outbreak in 2003. For example, radiologists can now report scans remotely 176 from other locations with the use of electronic medical records, radiology information systems (RIS), 177 and picture archiving and communication system (PACS). 178

Within the radiology department, further physical segregation can be performed. Unlike 179 radiographers and nurses who have to be on-site, radiologists can potentially report from home via 180 teleradiology. However, this may not be feasible for many centres to perform on a large scale due to 181 inherent differences in technical and economic support. In Singapore, healthcare institutions face a 182 unique situation of "internet separation". The option of teleradiology is non-feasible locally as the 183 Singapore Government has terminated direct access to the internet from the hospital's internal 184 systems due to previous cyber-attacks [17] . 185

Hence, our department has implemented physical segregation by dividing reporting areas into 186 "dirty" (i.e. high risk) and "clean" (i.e. low risk) areas. Reporting rooms which are close to areas with 187 high patient flow and contact (e.g. ultrasound, fluoroscopy, inpatient CT scanners) are classified as 188 "dirty", with the remaining rooms classified as "clean". Radiologists reporting in the "dirty" rooms 189 would be isolated within the rooms during working hours, with no interaction with colleagues in the 190 "clean" rooms. This is achievable in part due to Singapore's experience with SARS, where we have 191 learnt to segregate outpatient and inpatient areas by building separate out-and in-patient wings in 192 the same hospital to minimise cross contamination. Hence, the department is distributed over 193 several satellite reporting areas, rather than a single 'central' reporting area. By adopting these strategies, the extent of team/group quarantine could be further minimized in the event of staff 195 infection. It is also easier to take necessary actions including disinfection of workplace and 196 equipment that had contact with the identified staff. 197
Potential challenges could arise in radiology departments with unique architecture layout where 198 inhibition of human traffic may impair workflow patterns. To overcome these issues, departments 199

can consider the use of technology in the form of hospital endorsed online meeting platforms to 200 disseminate information. One example would be to alert radiology staff on the location and timing 201 of radiology scans for confirmed or suspected cases of COVID-19 in the department. 202

Implementation of both temporal and physical segregation policies may seem excessive. However, 204 departments can adopt variations of the temporal and/or physical segregation strategies to best suit 205 their needs. Ultimately, the segregation strategy implemented aims to achieve a balance between 206
(1) meeting clinical demands, (2) maintaining team spirit/morale, (3) reducing extent of disease 207 spread should it occur while (4) not compromising the safety of patients and staff. 208

While physical segregation of radiology staff serves to limit intra-department staff interactions, 211 additional steps can be implemented to limit inter-departmental staff interactions. These inter-212 departmental interactions may be unscheduled interactions, such as doctors coming to the 213 department for urgent scans request and/or discussion, or scheduled interactions such as multi-214 disciplinary meetings. These inter-departmental interactions increase the risk of disease 215 transmission and hence should be limited. 216

Our department has now restricted access of doctors from other departments, apart from urgent 217 reasons such as accompanying unstable patients for imaging studies or procedures. Face-to-face scan requests or discussions are now replaced by phone discussion or text messages through a 219 secured network. Scheduled interactions, such as multi-disciplinary meetings, are performed 220 through third party video-conferencing applications (e.g. Zoom) to facilitate complex patient care 221 discussions, while maintaining physical segregation. 222

On a social level, lunch meetings or after office hours social gatherings between colleagues are 223 discouraged during this period, as is attendance at professional conferences and seminars. This is to 224 minimise congregation of healthcare workers from different institutions or different countries. 225

Our radiology department is heavily involved in undergraduate and post-graduate radiology 227 education for domestic and international students and radiologists. With the COVID-19 outbreak, 228 medical students have been barred from hospitals to minimize staff-to-student and student-to-229 patient interactions. 230

To continue delivery of radiology education, large group lectures have been converted to online 231 modules with either a pre-recorded voice-over or a real-time online teaching session, whereby 232 students can dial-in to participate in a live Q&A session. To supplement online lectures, materials 233 have also been uploaded for students to review. In addition, our overseas medical student elective 234 program has been put on hold due to the current worldwide outbreak. Room. After positioning and preparation of the patient for the scan, the "dirty" radiographer then 299 exits the scan room to a dedicated waiting area without removing the PPE (Waiting Area) while the 300 "clean" radiographer remains stationed in the CT Control Room to complete the CT study. Upon scan 301 completion, the "dirty" radiographer re-enters the scan room and assists in moving the patient off 302 the scanner. The "dirty" radiographer would then remove the outer gloves and begins cleaning the 303 equipment including the power injector. The "dirty" radiographer then removes the PPE in a 304 dedicated changing area (Doffing area) and performs hand hygiene prior to exiting the scan room. 305 306 TAKE HOME POINTS
• Radiology departments should ensure adequate portable imaging capabilities, manpower demands and personal protective equipment (PPE) stock in this time of outbreak.
• Strict infection control practices, heightened levels of hygiene and rigorous cleaning are essential in reducing spread of COVID-19.
• Physical and temporal staff segregations with deliberate limitation of staff-to-staff interactions play a role in reducing disease spread while maintaining hospital services.

back_matter.text: The COVID-19 outbreak has created chaos and disrupted many routines globally. Radiology being 242 one of the important assessment tools is similarly affected. While some issues may be unique to 243 individual departments, the majority of challenges faced by Radiology departments globally are 244 similar. By sharing our experience,it is our hope that worldwide institutions may benefit from the 245 practical experiences and strategies implemented in our department. 246 247
